newsitem.title: USA: Oklahoma prosecution case study in professionalism.
newsitem.headline: Oklahoma prosecution case study in professionalism.

text.p: This is not the O.J. case.

From putting drill bits and a phone card into evidence to offering up heart-wrenching testimony and painting a portrait of a man at war with his government, the prosecution in the Oklahoma City bombing case is quickly building its case.

Legal experts say the prosecution against 29-year-old Gulf War veteran Timothy McVeigh could be completed within three weeks -- much faster than expected -- if the prosecution maintains the serious, no nonsense approach it has delivered in the first two weeks of the case.

Their presentation is in sharp contrast to the prosecution meandering and battles with the defence that marked the O.J. Simpson double-murder case, a case that many Americans have, for good or ill, equated with how the justice system works.

One legal expert said the bombing case prosecution's team-like professionalism is aided by a judge who is in complete charge and who takes no nonsense from lawyers -- even to the point of barring lawyers from talking to the press and putting their spin on a day's proceedings. In stark contrast, the Simpson murder case was a never-ending media circus.

"Federal Judge Richard Matsch, in contrast to Simpson case Judge Lance Ito, exercises complete control over the courtroom. He's really trying to keep control of the trial," said Robert Precht, director of the Office of Public Service at the University of Michigan Law School.
The prosecution strategy is to alternate between the dull and the dramatic -- between putting drill bits and a padlock into evidence to bringing on McVeigh's own sister to testify.

"I think they are trying to choreograph it to make it focused and as interesting as they can. It's looking very smooth," said William Pizzi, a professor at the University of Colorado Law School and a former federal prosecutor.
"What the prosecution is trying to do in the courtroom is keep the jurors interested. They go from dramatic to dry to dramatic," said Precht.
Prosecutors are building their case against McVeigh by introducing circumstantial evidence they claim proves a conspiracy to build a bomb and then plant it at the Alfred P. Murrah federal building.

That circumstantial evidence includes drill holes found on a padlock protecting dynamite sticks that were stolen to a pre-paid telephone calling card to fingerprints found on receipts for motel bills and a huge purchase of fertiliser that could have been used to build the bomb.
The prosecution has also presented some very emotional testimony from people who were working in the Murrah building on April 19, 1995 when the blast occurred, killing 168 people.

"It's a very cleverly scripted strategy," Precht said and one very much in contrast to the World Trade Centre bombing trial where the prosecution presented scientific and physical evidence before introducing the human element.

The first witness the prosecution presented was Lou Klaver, an attorney with the Oklahoma Water Resources Board, located across the street from the Murrah building. She played a tape of a routine board meeting on the day of the bombing. After two minutes of voices, the tape plays a huge roar, crashes and the frightened shout of "Let's get out of here."
Other victims of the bombing -- the worst civilian attack on U.S. soil -- then took the stand to tell their stories.

The courtroom became charged again when Lori Fortier, wife of former McVeigh friend Michael Fortier, testified under a grant of immunity from prosecution and told how McVeigh wanted to avenge the deaths of some 80 members of the Branch Davidian cult in a showdown with the government on April 19, 1993.

"They have terrific motive evidence -- an overpowering hatred of the government," Pizzi said. It is very important for jurors to see and understand the motive for a defendant's behaviour because it gives credence to the evidence, he said.

The most dramatic testimony to date came from McVeigh's sister Jennifer, who testified that her brother wrote her in the weeks before the bombing that "something big is going to happen" and that she burned that letter on his instructions.
Her testimony was followed by the dull -- dozens of telephone company executives who introduced records of calls the government claims McVeigh made while planning the bombing.
